problemStatement.formal: ∀ n : ℕ, ∃ p : ℕ, Nat.Prime p ∧ p > n ∧ p % 4 = 3
problemStatement.plain: There are infinitely many primes congruent to 3 modulo 4.
whyMatters: Special case of Dirichlet's theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions
Demonstrates the distribution of primes across residue classes
This case admits an elementary proof without analytic number theory

proven: infinitely_many_primes_3_mod_4: ∀ n : ℕ, ∃ p : ℕ, Nat.Prime p ∧ p > n ∧ p % 4 = 3
primes_3_mod_4_infinite: Set.Infinite {p : ℕ | Nat.Prime p ∧ p % 4 = 3}
no_largest_prime_3_mod_4: ¬∃ p, Nat.Prime p ∧ p % 4 = 3 ∧ ∀ q, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 3 → q ≤ p

knowledge.progressSummary: COMPLETE: Elementary Euclid-style proof in InfinitudePrimes4k3.lean. Uses N = 4·(n+1)! - 1 construction. No analytic machinery required.
builtItems: InfinitudePrimes4k3.has_prime_factor_3_mod_4 - key lemma: n ≡ 3 mod 4 has prime factor ≡ 3 mod 4
InfinitudePrimes4k3.factors_determine_mod_four - if all odd prime factors ≡ 1 mod 4, then n ≢ 3 mod 4
InfinitudePrimes4k3.prime_mod_four - odd primes are 1 or 3 mod 4
InfinitudePrimes4k3.mul_mod_four_one - product of 1 mod 4 stays 1 mod 4
insights: N ≡ 3 mod 4, so N must have at least one prime factor ≡ 3 mod 4
This prime p > n since p ∤ (n+1)! (as p ∣ N = 4·(n+1)! - 1 and p ∣ 4·(n+1)! would imply p ∣ 1)
Product of integers ≡ 1 mod 4 stays ≡ 1 mod 4, so N can't factor entirely into 4k+1 primes
This proof is completely elementary - no Dirichlet or analytic NT needed
Strong induction handles the factorization argument cleanly
